author: potuz
content: You don't need to keep any IL at all except to serve other peers requesting  them. You **only** care that you have already seen a valid one and that's it. Your EL may keep the txs in the mempool cause if you're proposing it will have to honor it. But the CL does not care about the IL after it has validated that it's available

author: g11tech
content:
can we also discuss <@360491619402776577> 's proposal here :

my understanding is it has three flaws which have been pointed out but here is my understanding of them

1. JIT availability of txs to builders: 

   - If the getHeader  or newILTxs  call goes out to relays earlier than slot boundary (signed by the proposer of the incoming slot), then builders can pull it from relays and include it in their block if they want. we can also limit the num txs to 16 as well as cumulative gas consumption

2. Builder might actually censor the txs by giving you an invalid payload which the proposer will only figure out when it signs the blindedblock and gives it to builder to reveal its payload : 

  - If the builder causes a missed proposal soon enough they/or relay will be blacklisted by proposers

3. Builders might not build optimal blocks:

  - including the txs towards end of block doesn't constraint builder if the IL order is not forced on builder, which anyway is not the intend of the current task. censoring builders not responding with any bid, might be net postive for the ecosystem?

I also understand that this could be incompatible with the ePBS design but I need to dig through that to make that determination for myself. so am keeping myself open ended about that

author: potuz
content:
Afaik the current proposal being discussed in ACD is EIP-7547 and the only arguments now are for minor nuances over the design, and not the design itself, that is:
- should the summary be committed to the block or not
- should the proposer be allowed to send different summaries or just different txs for the same summary.
- should the builder decide which summary to include or should the proposer

All these three are the same choice. When this EIP went up for discussion people started offering very different approaches, Marius' for example is based in his not liking that the proposer for N forces inclusion to the proposer of N+1. 

I believe a large part of these problems arise because R&D is carried in closed channels in telegram or in small EF research retreats. This has been always a grudge with Ethereum research: we changed substantially the way withdrawals are handled just a few months before the Capella fork. We complained about sync committee variance just before Altair, etc.

author: potuz
content: If the whole IL channel would have been visible here, it wouldn't have deterred discussions since anyway people don't really participate from technical discussions, and it would have been now much easier to point to new proposers of points in the past where those designs were already discussed. This is why I've advocated for an ePBS channel here, hoping to not be the only voice constantly pushing to have that in soon

author: terence0083
content:
Some thoughts on builder API with the current design 

- With `submitBlindBlock`, what are the disadvantages of not returning the signed inclusion list to the relayer for verification against the block.summary_root? Is it feasible for a proposer to employ the same unbundling strategy against the builder? For instance, the proposer could provide an incorrect summary root to the builder, wait for the builder to gossip the block, and then unbundle it using the correct summary root. This strategy seems impractical within a 4s but might be acceptable if all clients mandatorily reorg late blocks...
- It is crucial that a client can import more than one IL to prevent the previously mentioned attack. A proposer can create two valid inclusion lists, IL#1 and IL#2, that match the same summary. The proposer broadcasts IL#1 and sends IL#2 along with submitBuildBlock. A consensus node will import IL#1, gossip it, and then import IL#2...
- Considering all of this, would it be more effective to couple the block directly with its inclusion list as a p2p object? (not consensus object). Still thinking...
